Job.JobDescription:
The Coach 2025 role at Leonor Nava emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach 2025 coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Leonor Nava, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach 2025 reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Leonor Nava at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach 2025 may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach 2025 monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach 2025 must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Leonor Nava.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach - Girls Volleyball (Leuzinger) (REPOST)
Job.JobDescription: POSITION: Assistant Coach - Girls Volleyball (Leuzinger) (REPOST) DURATION: 2025-2026 School Year LOCATION(S): Leuzinger High School COMPENSATION: Coaching stipend per Collective Bargaining Agreement for current employees / Coaching stipend of $4,476 per season for walk-on coaches DESCRIPTION: To assist the Head Coach with organizing the Girls Volleyball program at the site. To assist with coaching and supervising the Girls Volleyball program. To act as a liaison between the Head Coach and the community. MINIMUM QUALIFICATION(S): * NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching or Sport Specific * NFHS Concussion in Sports (every 2 years) * NFHS Sudden Cardiac Arrest (every 2 years) * NFHS Heat Illness Prevention (every 2 years) * Valid CPR/First-Aid card * At least two years of experience as a varsity coach at the high school, college, or professional level in the sport applying for * Experience as a college or professional athlete * Demonstrated success with the development of a team with high academic achievement DESIRABLE QUALIFICATION(S): * At least two years of experience as a varsity coach at the high school, college, or professional level in the sport applying for * Experience as a college or professional athlete * Demonstrated success with the development of a team with high academic achievement APPLICATION PROCEDURE: To be considered for this position, ALL applicants (Walk-On or Certificated) must complete the online application, which can be found at: https://www.applitrack.com/centinelak12ca/onlineapp/ If you need assistance with the online application, please contact Human Resources at 310-263-3200. The Human Resources office is located at 14901 S. Inglewood Avenue, Lawndale, CA 90260. DEADLINE TO APPLY: Until Filled WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO REOPEN, READVERTISE, DELAY, OR CANCEL FILLING THIS POSITION Please note: Applicants selected to participate in an interview may be asked to share playbooks, athlete expectations, conditioning plans, academic achievement plans, winning stats, etc. during the interview process. Job Summary: The Assistant Coach is responsible for supporting the Head Coach in supervision and preparation of players in the program. Assistant Coaches are required to follow the game plan and expectations set by the Head Coach and support the aspects of the program as assigned by the Head Coach. Assistant Coaches must abide by rules and regulations set forth by the CIF and Centinela Valley Union High School District, as well as the athletic administration. Job Specifications: In order to be successful in this job, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skills and/or abilities required. Reasonable accommodation may be made to enable individuals with disabilities, who are otherwise qualified, to perform the essential functions. Essential Responsibilities: * Supervise athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions, to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, discipline, respect, and good sportsmanship. * Prepare field/courts on Game Day and support logistics as directed by the Head Coach * Use a variety of instructional techniques and media to meet the needs and improve the abilities of student-athletes. * Assess players' skills * Support game strategy as determined by the Head Coach * Apply and enforce student discipline during athletic contests, practice sessions, and while on trips off school property. * Encourage sportsmanlike conduct in all phases of athletic participation at all times (coaches and athletes) * Take all necessary precautions to protect student-athletes, equipment, and facilities, including protecting students from hazing/bullying. * Maintain and secure all equipment and uniforms. * Oversee the process of cleaning, repairing, and storing all athletic equipment. * Represent the Centinela Valley Union High School District and program in a professional manner. * Maintain nondiscriminatory practices in all activities. * Attend staff development meetings, clinics, and other professional activities to improve coaching performance. * Perform any other related duties as assigned by the Athletic Director or other appropriate administrator. Additional Knowledge/Skills/Attributes/Certificates: Knowledge: * Comprehensive knowledge of the game is paramount. Extensive knowledge of current coaching techniques and procedures. * Knowledge of NFHS and CIF rules and regulations. * Demonstrated ability to instruct and supervise student-athletes. Skills: * The applicant must possess the ability to communicate in spoken and written word. * Excellent organizational, communication, and interpersonal skills. * The applicant must possess the ability to relate to students and to teach them on and off the field. * The applicant must be willing to accept a high level of accountability. Attributes: * The applicant should be professionally calm and motivationally intense. Certificates: * NFHS Fundamentals of Coaching or Sport Specific * NFHS Concussion in Sports (every 2 years) * NFHS Sudden Cardiac Arrest (every 2 years) * NFHS Heat Illness Prevention (every 2 years) * Valid CPR/First-Aid card Supervision Exercised: N/A Supervision Received: Principal /Athletic Director, Head Coach
Job.SalaryRange: Coaching stipend per Collective Bargaining Agreement for current employees / Coaching stipend of $4,476 per season for walk-on coaches

Job.JobTitle: JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School at Dave Bacigalupi is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Dave Bacigalupi, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Dave Bacigalupi operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Dave Bacigalupi with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the JV Head Coach Flag Football - Oakdale High School role at Dave Bacigalupi.

The Athletic Coaches | Soledad High School position at Kirk Cooper is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Athletic Coaches | Soledad High School works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach role at Vickie Castro emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Vickie Castro, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Vickie Castro at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Wrestling Coach must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Vickie Castro.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School (2025/2026 School Year) - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach role at Vickie Castro is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Vickie Castro, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Vickie Castro, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School - including 7th/8th Grade Co-Ed Track Coach at Vickie Castro is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School (2025/2026 School Year)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School at Vickie Castro is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Vickie Castro reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Athletic Coaches | Main Street Middle School may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Vickie Castro. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: JV Head Coach- Baseball
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Head Coach- Baseball at Eureka City Schools is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the JV Head Coach- Baseball is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Eureka City Schools, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The JV Head Coach- Baseball helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The JV Head Coach- Baseball works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Eureka City Schools operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Eureka City Schools with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the JV Head Coach- Baseball reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the JV Head Coach- Baseball role at Eureka City Schools.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School at Angela Lippert is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Angela Lippert, the Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Angela Lippert well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Lacrosse Coach - Pacific Grove High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: JV Softball Coach (2025-2026)- GHS
Job.JobDescription:
The JV Softball Coach - GHS at Adam Cano is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the JV Softball Coach - GHS are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Adam Cano use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The JV Softball Coach - GHS recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the JV Softball Coach - GHS collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The JV Softball Coach - GHS maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Adam Cano. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Coaching Fall, Winter, and Spring. Temporary Seasonal Positions
Job.JobDescription:
Comprised of approximately 1700 students, FBUSD is the second largest school district in Mendocino County. With a wide array of athletic teams, a strong academic program, and an extensive range of extra-curricular options, FBUSD students continually have an impressive range of options after high school. The Fort Bragg community is incredibly supportive of all school activities and events and donates generously to programs and scholarships.
Job Summary Hello Coaches: You can apply in person (applications are available at school sites) or an EDJoin application. If you have prior coaching employment, you will submit a letter of interest to the school site sports secretary.
Once hired, you will need to complete all requirements before coaching. Once you are selected for the position, new coaching employee packets will be given. All requirements must be completed prior to coaching. Coaching stipends are prorated and paid monthly. Anyone filling in for or assisting a coach must get TB and fingerprint clearance before working with children. Forms are available at the District Office. You can call (707) 961-3502 to request the specific forms. Anyone working with students who do not possess a valid CPR/First Aid Certificate must always be in the presence of a certificated coach. All requirements must be met according to the California Interscholastic Federation CIF By-law.
If transporting students, you must have an approved driver application on file. A Clear DMV report and specific insurance coverage requirements apply.
Ask Site Secretaries for availability. All coaching positions run annually. For more information, call the District Office Human Resource (707) 961-3502; school site sports secretaries can be reached at Fort Bragg Middle School 961-2870 or Fort Bragg High School (707) 961-2880
Job Description / Essential Elements: DEFINITION Under general supervision, to assist in the coaching of a sport, to instruct students in the rules and fundamentals of a sport, and to do related work as required.
SUPERVISION Works under the supervision of the Athletic Director and Principal. Will be evaluated by the Athletic Director and the Principal.
Requirements / Qualifications MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS • Establishes performance criteria for eligibility in interscholastic competition in his/her sport. • Enforces discipline and sportsman like behavior at all times, and establishes and oversees penalties for breach of such standards by individual students. Employee and volunteer requirements must be met before working with students (Fingerprint clearance, TB Test/Assessment Clearance, CPR/First Aid Certification, NFHS Fundamentals, Concussion, and Keenan mandatory online classes, etc.).
Paychecks will not be authorized until all requirements have been met. In addition, anyone who does not have a CPR/First Aid Certificate must always be in the presence of a certified coach.
CODE OF ETHICS §5595 Recertification of Temporary Athletic Team Coaches - Once a district has determined that a coach meets the provisions of Section 5593, the district may recertify the coach. §5596 Code of Ethical Conduct - Each school district shall, no later than 90 days subsequent to the filing of this chapter with the Secretary of State, implement the following listed standards of ethical conduct for each temporary, probationary, or permanent employee of a school district providing supervisory and instructional services in interscholastic athletic programs and activities. Any specified person providing such services to the district shall: a. Show respect for players, officials, and other coaches. b. Respect the integrity and judgment of game officials. c. Establish and model fair play, sportsmanship, and proper conduct. d. Establish player safety and welfare as the highest priority. e. Provide proper supervision of students at all times. f. Use discretion when providing constructive criticism and when reprimanding players. g. Maintain consistency in requiring all players to adhere to the established rules and standards of the game to be played. h. Properly instruct players in the safe use of equipment. i. Avoid exerting undue influence on a pupil's decision to enroll in an athletic program at any public or private post-secondary educational institution. j. Avoid exerting undue influence on pupils to take the lighter academic course(s) in order to be eligible to participate in interscholastic athletics.
Comments and Other Information Please ask the site secretaries for the current coaching availability and schedule.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Trainer
Job.JobDescription: Position Information: The Athletic Trainer position oversees the healthcare management of assigned sports, and serves as the primary point of contact between sports medicine, coaching staff, and student-athletes. The Athletic Trainer collaborates closely with team physicians, strength and conditioning staff, dietitians, and mental health professionals to develop individualized performance and injury prevention programs that optimize student-athlete health and performance. This position is responsible for the prevention, evaluation, treatment, and rehabilitation of athletic injuries and illnesses while ensuring compliance with NCAA, conference, and institutional health and safety standards. The Athletic Trainer also plays a critical role in enhancing the student-athlete experience by fostering a culture of health, safety, and performance excellence while contributing to the advancement of sports medicine services at the institution. The full salary range for the Athletic Trainer is $68,500 - $121,900 annually. We base salary offers on a variety of considerations, such as education, licensure and certifications, experience, and other business and organizational needs. Applicants must have current work authorization when accepting a UCR staff position. Currently, we are unable to sponsor or take over sponsorship of an employment Visa for staff. As a University employee, you will be required to comply with all applicable University policies and/or collective bargaining agreements, as may be amended from time to time. Federal, state, or local government directives may impose additional requirements. Requirements: Educational Requirements (Degree - Bachelor's degree in related area. Required; Master's degree in related field. Preferred), Experience Requirements (Experience - Minimum of 3 years of experience directly related to the duties and responsibilities specified. Required; Experience in a collegiate setting is preferred. Preferred), Certification Requirements (Certification - Professional certification. Required; First Aid, CPR and AED Required), Special Conditions (Travel Outside of Normal Business Hours Required; Travel Required; Work schedule will include evening and weekend hours. Required; Valid Drivers License Required), Minimum Requirements (Computer skills in programs relevant to job duties. Thorough skills associated with athletic injury prevention and the administration of therapeutic modalities, devices, and rehabilitation techniques, as well as of first-aid, athletic equipment, and injury assessment and treatment. Ability to maintain discretion and confidentiality in handling sensitive matters involving athletic injuries and treatments. Thorough knowledge of electronic medical records systems. For positions associated with Sports Medicine, must maintain current knowledge of applicable rules and standards of the affiliated athletic conference, the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) or National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics (NAIA), as well as other associations and agencies to which the campus adheres, and, at all times, avoid any and all violations of these rules and standards). Additional Information: At the University of California, Riverside, we embrace and celebrate diversity in all its forms. We are committed to creating and maintaining a safe, fair, and respectful environment for our students, faculty, and staff. We are proud to be an equal opportunity employer and value individuals from all backgrounds, cultures, and experiences. UCR is a world-class research university with an exceptionally diverse undergraduate student body. Its mission is explicitly linked to providing routes to educational success for underrepresented and first-generation college students. A commitment to this mission is a preferred qualification. The University of California is an Equal Opportunity/Affirmative Action Employer. All qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, disability, protected veteran status, or any other characteristic protected by law. Job.JobTitle: Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls)
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls) role at MIRA LOMA HIGH SCHOOL is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls) is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At MIRA LOMA HIGH SCHOOL, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls) sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At MIRA LOMA HIGH SCHOOL, the Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls) is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Head Coach, Varsity Swimming (Boys and Girls) at MIRA LOMA HIGH SCHOOL is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Director - Mesa Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
NOTICE OF VACANCY ATHLETIC DIRECTOR 2025-2026 SCHOOL YEAR
POSITION: Athletic Director - Mesa Middle School Mesa Middle School is looking for an Athletic Director for the 2025-2026 school year.
STIPEND: Middle School Athletic Director Stipend: $4,100/yr
Athletic Salary Schedule information listed on page 3 of the Certificated Salary Schedule.
POSITION PURPOSE: To manage and coordinate athletic activities and sports programs to promote athletics and physical fitness as positive extra-curricular activities, and to ensure that all students have an equal opportunity to participate and share in the benefits of the district's athletic programs.
DESCRIPTION: Under the direct supervision of the middle school principal, the athletic director will assist in the planning, development, and implementation of the policies, regulations, guidelines, and procedures pertaining to a school site interscholastic sports program: serve as a resource to administrators and interscholastic sports personnel concerning sports and recreation activities; other related functions as directed.
T he A th letic D irector w ill be the prim ary educator, overseer, enforcer, and interpreter of A th letic regulations. T he A th letic D irector w ill utilize all the resources available to establish a cooperative relationship w ith parents, staff m em bers and adm inistrators to support each student's opportunity to learn and grow in educational and life experiences. T he goal of the A th letic D irector is to provide overall leadership and coordination am ong the various sports and provide student athletes w ith a positive com petitive experience.
MINIMUM REQUIRED QUALIFICATIONS: • Bachelor's Degree from an accredited college or university in a related field. • Hold and maintain First Aid, CPR certification and Valid California Driver’s License • Experience: As mandated by the state, and accepted by the school district. ? • DOJ and FBI Background Clearance.
DESIRED QUALIFICATIONS: • Credential: Valid California teaching credential with an authorization to teach any subject matter in grades 7-12 in a departmentalized setting. Specific type of credential shall be determined based on need. CLAD/BCLAD/EL Authorization. • Degree, including all courses and/or exams needed to meet credentialing and subject matter competency.
Qualities, Experience and Knowledge: • Excellent interpersonal, oral and written communication skills. Highly self-directed with an attention to detail and ability to organize effectively. Resourceful, innovative, helpful, diligent, persistent, and willingness to work with colleagues and students. • Successful experience managing or directing the athletic programs or a school district preferred. • Knowledge of athletics, athletic programs, and physical fitness. • Knowledge of applicable federal and state laws and regulations regarding school district athletic programs, safety and health, and other areas under responsibility. • Ability to understand, apply and use personal computers and software applications • Ability to evaluate, develop and implement athletic programs, activities and events, and make effective recommendations related to those areas. • Ability to organize multiple tasks and conflicting time constraints. • Ability to engage in self-evaluation with regard to leadership, performance and professional growth. • Ability to establish and maintain cooperative working relationships with others contacted in the course of work.

Comments and Other Information This school district/County Office does not discriminate on the basis of actual or perceived race, color, ancestry, national origin, age, religion, religious creed, political affiliation, gender, gender identity, gender expression, mental or physical disability, medical condition, marital status, sex, sexual orientation, genetics, or any other basis protected by federal, state or local law, ordinance or regulation, in its education program(s) or employment. No person shall be denied employment solely because of any impairment which is unrelated to the ability to engage in activities involved in the position(s) or program for which application been made.
State law requires all of our employees to be fingerprinted for the purpose of a confidential background investigation and prohibits the commencement of employment until the background investigation has been completed. Proof of freedom from active tuberculosis based upon an intra-dermal test must be furnished at time of employment. Public Law 99-603 (Immigration, Naturalization & Control Act of 1986) requires that all employees hired after November 6, 1986 provide proof of work eligibility. Therefore, if hired please be prepared to present appropriate documentation verifying identity and ability to work legally in the U.S. Any applicant who attempts to contact individual Board members or members of the screening or interview committees with the intent of influencing the decision of the committee and/or Board will be disqualified.

Job.JobTitle: Varsity Football Coach
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer Located in northern California Wine Country, the Ukiah Unified School District serves approximately 6,000 students, from preschoolers through adults. The district includes six elementary schools, two middle schools, and a comprehensive high school. In addition, our district offers an early education preschool, independent learning opportunities for elementary and high school students, an alternative education high school, and an adult learning center. Located in Mendocino County, Ukiah has countless wineries, is a short drive to the coast, and is surrounded by redwood forests. Our employees enjoy the best of California in a welcoming and caring community.
When you join Ukiah Unified, you become part of an amazing and vibrant community. We have wonderful assets for raising a family, including Near & Arnold’s School of Performing Arts & Cultural Education (SPACE), an acclaimed afterschool performing arts program serving youth ages infant through 18. The program emphasizes diversity, youth leadership, cross-cultural arts, social issues, and exemplary training in the arts. We’re adjacent to Sonoma County and the culinary epicenter of Healdsburg. A farm-to-table lifestyle is possible thanks to the abundant agricultural resources in and around Ukiah. Imagine access to orchards, fresh fruit, vegetables, artisan olive oils, farm-fresh artisan cheese, wild-caught seafood, and the top wineries in the country. And, of course, community-supported schools where education and educators are valued. Plus, Mendocino County and the city of Ukiah offer some of the most affordable housing in California! We invite you to apply to be part of Ukiah Unified and our wonderful community.
Requirements / Qualifications CPR Certificate First Aid Certificate Coaching Fundamentals Concussion Certificate TB test Fingerprints

Job.JobTitle: Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School role at Lisette Nunez is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Lisette Nunez are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Lisette Nunez, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Girls Basketball Frosh/Soph Coach - Mission Viejo High School at Lisette Nunez, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School role at Mike Do emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Mike Do, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Mike Do at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach - Boys Frosh/Soph Baseball - Santa Teresa High School must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Mike Do.

Job.JobTitle: Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School at North Salinas High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At North Salinas High School, the Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents North Salinas High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Varsity Volleyball Coach (Girls) - North Salinas High School follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.

Job.JobTitle: Director, Golf Operations & Head Coach - Men's & Women's Golf
Job.JobDescription:
The Director, Golf Operations & Head Coach - Men's & Women's Golf at University of La Verne is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Director, Golf Operations & Head Coach - Men's & Women's Golf plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at University of La Verne reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Director, Golf Operations & Head Coach - Men's & Women's Golf expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. Job.JobTitle: Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26)
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26) position at Chapman University provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26) prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Chapman University, the Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26) works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26) encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Athletics- Intramural ('25-'26) at Chapman University is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.

Culture is a central focus of this job. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. Job.JobTitle: Athletic Teaching Assistant
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Teaching Assistant role at San Diego Community College District emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Athletic Teaching Assistant coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At San Diego Community College District, the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Athletic Teaching Assistant reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent San Diego Community College District at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Athletic Teaching Assistant may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Athletic Teaching Assistant monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Athletic Teaching Assistant must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at San Diego Community College District.
Job.CompanyDescription: San Diego Community College District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard
Job.JobDescription:
The Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard position at California Institute of Tech is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At California Institute of Tech, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Occasional (On-Call) Lifeguard role at California Institute of Tech is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

The Assistant Coach - Men's Tennis role at University of the Pacific - Stockton Campus is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. Job.JobTitle: Strength And Conditioning Assistant- Hrly/Int POOL
Job.JobDescription: Job Summary: Under the immediate supervision of the Director of Sport Performance the incumbent will assist various sports teams with their strength and conditioning program. Key Responsibilities: Perform support services for student athletes in the strength complex as outlined by the Director of Sport Performance. Motivate student athletes with regards to strength and conditioning. Manage tracking of training sessions and test results. Assist with the enforcement and implementation of policies and procedures for the weight room. Knowledge Skills and Abilities: Demonstrated knowledge and commitment to University, NCAA, and Big West/Golden Coast/MPSF Conference rules and regulations. Ability to motivate student-athletes to perform to their optimal level. Strong organizational, communication, and computer skills. Ability to communicate with an ethnically and culturally diverse campus community. Ability to follow all university policies, procedures, and guidelines including but not limited to safety, civility, information security, and non-discrimination policies and procedures. Ability to contribute to a positive university experience for each and every student, and assist in achieving the university’s commitment to a “Vision of excellence.” Education and Experience: Equivalent to six months of related experience involving developing and implementing strength and conditioning based programming required. Bachelor's degree preferred. Physical Summary: Heavy work - Job involves lifting more than 40 pounds. Approximately half of the incumbent's time will be spent walking, standing, squatting, kneeling, or climbing. Licenses / Certificates: CPR/First Aid certification required. The National Strength Coaches Association’s CSCS certification (Certified Strength and Conditioning Specialist) or the Collegiate Strength and Conditioning Coaches Association’s SCCC certification (Strength and Conditioning Coach Certification) required. Division: Athletics Compensation: The salary range for this classification is $19.97 to $27.96 per hour. Time Base: POOL: Hourly/intermittent on call temporary position. Successful candidates may be appointed for a few days and up to one (1) year depending on the assignment. Temporary assignments may expire prior to the ending date. RECRUITMENT: This is a temporary hourly/intermittent position for one year with no permanent status granted. Classification: Instructional Support Assistant I Application Procedures: Click Apply Now to complete the CSULB Online Employment Application. PLEASE FILL OUT THE APPLICATION COMPLETELY. It is important that all sections of the on-line application are filled out completely and accurately. Please include all relevant education and experience. Your application will be used to determine whether you meet the minimum qualifications for this position Additional Information: The person holding this position is considered a 'mandated reporter' under the California Child Abuse and Neglect Reporting Act and is required to comply with the requirements set forth in CSU Executive Order 1083 Revised July 21, 2017 as a condition of employment. Long Beach State Athletics is committed to following NCAA, Big West Conference, Golden Coast Conference, and Mountain Pacific Sports Federation rules and regulations. Therefore, the incumbent is required to maintain a working knowledge of these rules and regulations. A background check (including a criminal records check) must be completed satisfactorily and is required for employment. CSU will make a conditional offer of employment, which may be rescinded if the background check reveals disqualifying information, and/or it is discovered that the candidate knowingly withheld or falsified information. Failure to satisfactorily complete the background check may affect the continued employment of a current CSU employee who was conditionally offered the position. Due to the nature of this position, current CSULB employees are subject to a criminal record check unless they have successfully completed a criminal background check through CSULB within the past 12 months. CSULB is not a sponsoring agency for staff and management positions (i.e. H-1B Visas). California State University Long Beach expects respectful, professional behavior from its employees in all situations. Acts of harassment or abusive conduct are prohibited. Demonstrated appropriate professional behavior, treating others with civility and respect, and refusing to tolerate abusive conduct is expected of all employees.
Job.Experience: Equivalent to six months of related experience involving developing and implementing strength and conditioning based programming required. Bachelor's degree preferred.

Job.JobTitle: Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025-2026
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025 role at Novato High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025 is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Novato High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025 sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Novato High School, the Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025 is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Coach (Head)-Track & Field JV Boys - Novato High School Spring 2025 at Novato High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.SalaryRange: Single Rate Walk On ($1983); NUSD Certificated ($3741) Stipend

Job.JobTitle: COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season
Job.JobDescription:
The COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season position at Rialto Unified School District is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Rialto Unified School District, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the COACH - BASKETBALL JP# 36 (Various Sites) - 2025/2026 Season role at Rialto Unified School District is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
