Job.JobDescription:
The COACH - VOLLEYBALL 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #9 at Veronica Herrera is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the COACH - VOLLEYBALL 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #9 manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Veronica Herrera, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The COACH - VOLLEYBALL 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #9 demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The COACH - VOLLEYBALL 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #9 follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the COACH - VOLLEYBALL 2025/2026 SEASON (Various Sites) - JP #9 at Veronica Herrera allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Sports Medicine Physician (Temp)
Job.JobDescription:
The Sports Medicine Physician (Temp) at San Jose State University is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Sports Medicine Physician (Temp) plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at San Jose State University reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Sports Medicine Physician (Temp) expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Sports Medicine Physician (Temp) supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Sports Medicine Physician (Temp) may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at San Jose State University. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.
Job.SalaryRange: Anticipated Hiring Range: $19,167 - $21,667 per month ($230,000 - $260,000 annually)

Job.JobTitle: Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College
Job.JobDescription:
The Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College position at Fullerton College is a key leadership role within the school's athletic program and wider learning community. This long-form description is designed to give prospective applicants a clear view of the expectations, responsibilities, and culture that surround the role. Coaches in this position are trusted to model character, support academic success, and help student‑athletes grow through meaningful experiences in practice, competition, and daily school life.
In this role, the Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College works closely with the athletic director, school administrators, and other coaches to design and maintain a structured, developmentally appropriate program. That includes planning practices that blend fundamental skill instruction, competitive drills, and situational teaching so athletes understand both the technical and strategic sides of the game. The coach is responsible for teaching core skills, reinforcing proper technique, and helping athletes safely build strength, conditioning, and sport‑specific endurance.
The position also focuses heavily on culture and leadership. The Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College at Fullerton College sets the tone for effort, respect, and sportsmanship. This involves building clear expectations for behavior, guiding athletes through wins and losses with perspective, and maintaining standards that reflect the values of the school and community. Student‑athletes should come away from the program with improved confidence, stronger communication skills, and a better understanding of teamwork and accountability.
Another important part of the job is collaboration. The coach regularly communicates with teachers, counselors, and families to help student‑athletes balance athletics with academics and other responsibilities. At Fullerton College, athletic participation is viewed as an extension of the classroom rather than a replacement for it. The Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College encourages students to stay organized, meet eligibility requirements, and pursue long‑term goals in the classroom as well as on the field or court.
Program operations also fall under this role. The coach helps manage equipment, uniforms, and facilities, and assists with scheduling, transportation coordination, and adherence to league and district policies. The Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College is expected to understand and follow all relevant regulations, including eligibility rules, sportsmanship guidelines, and safety standards, while maintaining current certifications such as CPR/First Aid as required by the district.
Finally, the Professional Expert (Temporary): Certified Athletic Trainer for Cypress College position at Fullerton College is a visible role that represents the school within the larger community. The coach interacts with families, officials, visiting teams, and youth programs, modeling professionalism in every setting. Candidates who are passionate about teaching, committed to student growth, and prepared to invest time and energy into the long‑term health of the program will find this role both challenging and rewarding.

Job.JobDescription:
The Head JV Football Coach at Santa Paula Unified School District is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Head JV Football Coach is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Santa Paula Unified School District, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Head JV Football Coach helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Head JV Football Coach works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Job.JobTitle: High School Cheer Coach
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer: The Aromas San Juan Unified School District is located in San Benito County with schools in San Juan Bautista and Aromas. We are 30 minutes north of Monterey and south of Santa Cruz.
ASJUSD is the only unified PK-12 collaborative learning community with a clear scope and sequence in academic and enrichment areas in San Benito County. Our TK-8 schools are multi-age communities, valuing the important developmental stages of children who learn together and from each other. We are a small sized learning community that is inclusive, responsive and agile to meet the needs of all students, giving them voice and agency to partner with us in their education.
We partner with our families and our community as we celebrate our diverse and rich culture, language, and customs. We seek to equip students to be multilingual, using languages of literacy and numeracy to make sense of the world and to recognize their responsibility to give back through service learning. We believe it is important that students have the joy of learning, through exploration and experiential learning.
We invite you to join us on our journey toward getting better. Excellence is our goal and we intend to be transparent about the progress we are making toward being a District of Distinction!
Job Summary: Anzar High School Cheer Coach
Requirements / Qualifications: Position Requirements: * Must have knowledge of rules, tactics, safety and conditioning aspects of Interscholastic Sports * Will be responsible for coordinating schedules and transportation to competitions. * Must have or be working towards completion of CIF Coaching Principles course * Must have current First Aid and CPR certificates * Required to complete background check, provide TB Clearance and complete mandated training. Please note, incomplete applications will not be considered. * Letter of Introduction * Letter(s) of Recommendation (2 Letters dated within the last 2 years. Letters submitted without dates, will be considered incomplete.) * Proof of HS Graduation (High School Diploma or GED) * Resume
Comments and Other Information: Aromas-San Juan USD is a small, rural school district located in San Benito, Monterey and Santa Cruz Counties. We are an easy commute from Hollister, Salinas, Watsonville, and Gilroy.
Aromas/San Juan Unified School District is an equal opportunity employer and does not discriminate based on race, color, national origin, religion, sex, disability, age, citizenship status, genetic information, ancestry, marital status, sexual orientation, gender identity and gender expression, medical condition, political activities or affiliations, or military or veteran status pursuant to the California Code. The Human Resources Department of the Aromas/San Juan Unified School District will make reasonable efforts in recruitment and examination process to accommodate applicants with disabilities. If you need an accommodation, please call (813) 623-4500.
Job.Location: Anzar High School, San Juan Bautista/Aromas, CA

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool
Job.JobDescription:
Description Under the general supervision of the Division Dean of Humanities, Social Science, Education, Kinesiology and Athletics, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) teaches organized classes primarily in the Coaching discipline; the primary responsibility is to teach up to 10 units (part-time) in the assigned discipline.
Responsibilities and Duties Duties and responsibilities may include, but not limited to the following: 1. Instruct courses in Coaching in accordance with credit course outlines approved by the Board of Trustees. 2. Maintain expertise in current teaching methods, discipline knowledge, and discipline specific technologies. 3. Assist students in achieving stated course objectives. Evaluate the progress of each student and notify students in need of counseling services and/or tutorial assistance. Track student learning outcomes and maintain records of student learning outcomes. 4. Participate in the departmental process of curriculum review, modification, and the assessment of student learning outcomes in order to make the program successful. 5. Support the Division Dean in cooperating with campus and community groups to provide programs, courses, and information relevant to the needs of the students and various programs. 6. Coordinate with other faculty in the selection of textbooks, audiovisual and other instructional materials. 7. Complete various reporting procedures as required for student evaluation, course reporting and budget development. 8. Assist the Division Dean in the preparation of required reports by providing requested information. 9. Attend various departmental, divisional and campus-wide activities and events as required. 10. Plan and complete approved professional development flex activities each semester. 11. Perform other necessary duties as assigned by the Division Dean and as outlined in Board Policy.
Qualifications MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS: * Any bachelor's degree and two years of professional experience, or any associate degree and six years of professional experience. * Sensitivity to and understanding of the diverse academic, socioeconomic, cultural, disability, and ethnic backgrounds of community college students.
DESIRABLE QUALIFICATIONS: * Previous experience coaching cheer. * Master's in physical education, exercise science, education with an emphasis in physical education, kinesiology, physiology of exercise, or adaptive physical education. * Experience in teaching postsecondary courses in Physical Education, Kinesiology and/or Health Education. * Demonstrated ability to adapt teaching strategies and techniques to different levels of students' ability and learning styles. * Demonstrated ability to adapt teaching strategies and techniques to students from different cultures and ethnic groups. * Demonstrated ability to use innovative and creative teaching techniques and equipment, including the use of multimedia hardware and software and on-line instructional techniques. * Demonstrated leadership in developing curriculum for discipline specific courses and/or programs. * Demonstrated leadership, ability, and desire to stay current in the field. * Demonstrated leadership and ability to work with business and industry in order to coordinate the educational program with the needs of the community. * Interest in or knowledge of teaching online and other distance education courses.
Supplemental Information Applicants in this pool will remain active for one year. After one year, applicants will receive an email with information on how to remain in the pool. NOTES: * If your degree title differs from the minimum qualifications listed above, you are requested to apply under the "equivalent" provision. * Applicants applying under the "equivalent" provision must attach details and explain how their academic preparation and/or professional experience is the equivalent of the degrees/minimum qualifications listed above. * If you have already been granted equivalency for this discipline, you must attach a copy of your determination form or letter. * Per AP 4115 State Authorization, Distance Education - Effective July 1, 2014, faculty members residing out of state will not be assigned to teach internet courses.
Application Instructions Applicants applying to this position are REQUIRED to complete and submit: 1. A San Joaquin Delta College District Application 2. Resume or Curriculum Vitae 3. Letter of Interest 4. Unofficial or Official Transcripts from College/University
NOTES: * Applications submitted without all required documents, listed above, will be disqualified. * Applicants indicating "see resume" on the application will not have that referenced experience considered for minimum qualifications, which may lead to the application being disqualified. * Only information (education, experience, etc.) listed on the application will be considered for minimum qualifications. * Applicants, including current San Joaquin Delta College District employees, are required to provide official transcripts if required to meet the minimum qualifications for the position. * Applicants are required to submit official transcripts within 60 days of the time of hire. * Graduate advising documents and grade reports will not be accepted as official transcripts. * Individuals who have completed college or university coursework at an institution in a country other than the United States must obtain a complete evaluation of foreign transcripts, degrees, and other relevant documents. * A foreign transcript evaluation is required any time foreign coursework is used to meet minimum qualifications and/or salary placement even if the foreign transcript has been accepted by a college or university in the United States. * Foreign transcript evaluations are ONLY accepted from NACES (The National Association of Credential Evaluation Services) agencies or evaluators.
Employer San Joaquin Delta College
Address 5151 Pacific Avenue Stockton, California, 95207
Phone 209-954-5056
Website http://www.deltacollege.edu
Job.CompanyDescription: San Joaquin Delta College coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Head Boys Lacrosse Coach - Northwood High School - Outside & Internal Candidates Apply Here
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer The Irvine Unified School District comprises a diverse population of more than 36,000 PK-12 students in one early childhood learning center, 24 elementary schools, five K-8 schools, six middle schools, five high schools and one alternative high school. IUSD schools have been nationally recognized for comprehensive programs in academics, the arts, and athletics.
Job Description / Essential Elements: Under general direction of the principal or designee, assist in the planning, development, and implementation of the policies, regulations, guidelines, and procedures pertaining to an interscholastic sports program; to serve as a resource concerning physical education and physical activity instruction; to instruct and train sports activities groups in attaining proficiency in sport related functions; and to do other related functions as directed
EXPERIENCE Two years of experience as an interscholastic sports coach, preferred, including two years of experience performing specialized physical education at the secondary school level. Training in the care and prevention of athletic injuries; practical experience in team athletic conditioning; knowledge of the rules and regulations pertaining to the specific sport; knowledge of growth and development and its implications for coaching the particular sport.
Requirements / Qualifications Please complete all sections of the application including at least 2 references to be complete.
Comments and Other Information For more information about the position please contact Northwood Athletic Director’s Erik Terry (ErikTerry@iusd.org) or Sierra Wang (SierraWang@iusd.org).

Job.JobTitle: Coach (Prop 28): Color Guard Caption Head - Oak Grove High School
Job.JobDescription:
**About the Employer** As one of California's largest high school districts, we offer rewarding and exciting employment opportunities that impact our students and community in a positive way. We offer a supportive team environment with a shared passion and common goal of providing students the education and skills they need to succeed in college and career. Apart from competitive salaries and 100% benefits coverage for employees and their dependents, we also focus on personal professional development. We are looking for enthusiastic individuals to join our team!
**Job Summary** The East Side Union High School District (ESUHSD) seeks a skilled and passionate Color Guard specialist to work with one or more of the district's high schools Marching Band and/or Winter Guard programs. Throughout the production, the coach will work alongside the credentialed teacher at District High School, supporting students of varying skill levels. This role includes design, rehearsal preparation, instruction, and performance support at one or more school sites, contributing to high-quality production for a diverse student body.
**Requirements / Qualifications** Qualifications/Certifications: •Experience in equipment and dance elements related to the Color Guard activity •Experience teaching high school-aged students •Experience teaching small and large group instruction Must complete Edjoin online application, and submit Resume and Letters of Recommendation/Reference. Selected candidates must pass fingerprint clearance and provide current TB test results PRIOR to employment. • Letter(s) of Recommendation • Resume (Please attach a current Resume)
**Comments and Other Information** Key Tasks/Duties: •Participate as an integral member of the production design team. Design choreography/movement and equipment elements for guard members •Coordinate staff responsibilities with other instructors •Assist the director with communicating program information to the Color guard members •Attend rehearsals and performances as scheduled with the director •Stay advised as to the director’s goals and agendas as to the timelines/deadlines for materials to be produced and/or learned by the students •Foster student creativity, discipline, and teamwork in a culturally responsive and inclusive environment Other Duties/Responsibilities: Seasonal tied to a specific season or production Marching Band=One season/production Winter Percussion=One season/production
Job.Location: San Jose, Santa Clara County, CA

Job.JobTitle: VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH
Job.JobDescription:
The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH at Unidos Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Unidos Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The VOLLEYBALL HEAD COACH maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Unidos Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.
Job.CompanyDescription: Napa Valley Univied School District coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Wrestling Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Summary: Under general supervision, assists in coaching duties for the sport assigned at California Baptist University. Assists with aspects of the program that may include administrative duties, recruitment, training and/or strength training for athletic competition by performing the following duties.
Essential Duties and Responsibilities: 1. Understand and agree to abide by the mission of CBU and the CBU Athletics Department. 2. Assist head coach in organizing, preparing, and conducting individual and team practices, training, and competition using sound principles and judgment consistent with the philosophy of CBU Athletics. 3. Assist with the design of workout programs and training routines to improve athletic performance. 4. Assist as directed with implementing and supervising athletic training, strength, and conditioning workouts; provides technical support and training to athletes as appropriate to the sport. 5. Responsible for bookings and execution of all team travel. 6. Participate in various fundraising, marketing, and promotion activities. 7. May perform administrative duties including ordering and maintaining equipment, monitoring budgets, and initiating correspondence. 8. Assist in coaching all sport practices throughout the season. 9. Monitor and coordinate team social media in cooperation with the sports information and marketing department. 10. Motivate team for maximum performance by utilizing motivational philosophies that meet the needs of the students and that are consistent with the CBU Athletic Program philosophy. 11. Display good sportsmanship in relationships with students, staff, officials, and opponents as consistent with NCAA policies regarding the principle of sportsmanship and ethical conduct. 12. Effectively manage time in a demanding work environment. 13. Assist in recruiting and following up with qualified student athletes by phone, e-mail, or through on-campus visits. Within the framework of CBU and NCAA policies, recruit prospective student-athletes who are of the level necessary to be successful academically and athletically. 14. Assist with video capture of competitions and film review with athletes. 15. Adhere to all, sport, institutional, conference and NCAA by-laws and regulations. 16. Ensure the physical, emotional, and social welfare of student-athletes
Supervisory Responsibilities: This position has no supervisory duties.
Other Knowledge Skills and Abilities: To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform each essential duty satisfactorily. The requirements listed below are representative of the knowledge, skill, and/or ability required. Demonstrated ability and willingness to live and uphold the University’s Christ-centered mission and values. Ability to communicate effectively, both orally and in writing. Strong interpersonal and communication skills and the ability to work effectively with a diverse faculty, staff, and student body. Ability to foster a cooperative work environment. Knowledge of applicable team or individual sports and playing rules. Demonstrated competitive coaching skills in area of sporting specialty. Organizing and coordinating skills. Knowledge of strengthening and conditioning programs and routines. Ability to make administrative/procedural decisions and judgments. Ability to read and follow technical instructions and manuals. Skills in the use of first aid procedures. Knowledge of CPR and emergency medical procedures. Ability to react calmly and effectively in emergency situations. Knowledge of supplies, equipment, and/or services ordering and inventory control. Ability to read, understand, follow, and enforce safety procedures. Ability to travel, including domestic/international air travel, and work nights/weekends and holidays. Ability to effectively assist the head coach in arranging home and away contests according to conference and NCAA requirements and submit travel paperwork and NCAA pass lists on time.
REQUIRED CERTIFICATION/PERMITS: A valid California Driver’s license is required.
PHYSICAL DEMANDS: The physical demands described here are representative of those that must be met by an employee to successfully perform the essential functions of this job, which may include sport specific activities such as participating in wrestling training with student-athletes. While performing the duties of this job the employee is regularly required to stand; walk, and sit. Requires visual acuity to read words and numbers and speaking and hearing ability sufficient to communicate in person or over the phone. Moderate physical activity. Requires handling of average-weight objects up to 25 pounds or standing and/or walking for more than four (4) hours per day. Reasonable accommodations may be made to enable individuals with disabilities to perform the essential functions.
WORK ENVIRONMENT: The work environment characteristics described here are representative of those an employee encounters while performing the essential functions of this job. The noise level in the work environment is usually moderate. Work involves moderate exposure to unusual elements, such as extreme temperatures, dirt, dust, fumes, smoke, unpleasant odors, and/or loud noises. Work environment involves some exposure to hazards or physical risks, which require following basic safety precautions.
Education and/or Experience: Bachelor’s degree from four-year college or university; and one to two years related experience and/or training; or equivalent combination of education and experience. NCAA experience preferred.
Job.Benefits: In addition to wages, CBU offers a robust suite of employee benefits.

Job.JobTitle: eSPORTS Head Coach - Corona High School 25-26 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer The Corona-Norco Unified School District is the largest school district in Riverside County and the seventh-largest district in California. The success of our students is a direct result of our incredible classified and certificated staff members, which is why we believe in empowering our employees through a dedicated effort for continual training and professional development. Additionally, all teachers and administrators have access to participate in our induction program.
Job Summary Corona-Norco is seeking a qualified applicant to fill the position of Head Varsity Coach.
Qualifications: • Demonstrated successful coaching for the specific sport for which applying. • Demonstrated knowledge of the fundamental skills and techniques, as well as the advanced techniques needed for competitive athletes. • Demonstrated personality and character traits appropriate to educational leadership. • Demonstrated ability to develop and maintain a disciplined program. • Demonstrated management and organizational skills. • High school varsity level, college playing, and/or coaching experience required in the specific sport for which applying. • CPR Training and First Aid Certification
Responsibilities: • Verify receipt of appropriate clearances from Human Resources and Athletic Director for assistant coaches before any participation with the team. • Plan and implement the scheduling of team activities, practices, and transportation. • Serve as an instructor and guide. Follow District policies, site procedures, and CIF rules and procedures. • Foster training in conduct, ethics, and sportsmanship for participants. • Assist participants in the development of physical and leadership skills. • Work closely with the assigned administrator or certificated designee to plan and implement activities and fundraisers. • Plan and implement tryouts that ensure equal opportunities for all students. Ensure that the selection process is fair, consistent and impartial. • Supervision of team before, during, and after practices, games, and sporting events. • Verify each team member is cleared by the Athletic Director before allowing them to try out or practice. • Collaborate with the Athletic Director before ordering athletic equipment. • Manage a safe and organized process of storage for equipment on campus. • Distribute and collect all equipment. Provide accurate inventory to the Athletic Director as needed. • Maintain open communication with parents
Requirements / Qualifications The following must be submitted with an application for interview consideration: (1) High School Diploma, GED, or College Transcripts (2) First Aid/CPR/AED Certification - must be valid through June 30, 2026; https://www.redcross.org/take-a-class/cpr/cpr-training/cpr-certification (3) Coaching Education Course (e.g. Fundamentals of Coaching Education or other CIF Approved equivalent) https://nfhslearn.com/courses/fundamentals-of-coaching (4) Concussion Awareness - issued on or after July 1, 2024 (5) Heat Illness Prevention in Student-Athletes - issued on or after July 1, 2024 (6) Sudden Cardiac Arrest - issued on or after July 1, 2024
Preferred Experience: Head varsity eSPORTS coaching experience
Comments and Other Information NON-DISCRIMINATION STATEMENT The Corona-Norco Unified School District is committed to equal opportunity for all individuals in education and in employment and does not discriminate on the basis of actual or perceived ancestry, age, color, physical or mental disability, medical condition, gender, gender identity, gender expression, nationality, national origin, immigration status, race or ethnicity, ethnic group identification, religion, sex, sexual orientation, marital or parental status, pregnancy, or genetic identification, or association with a person or group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics. The Board prohibits, at any district school or school activity, unlawful discrimination, harassment, intimidation, and bullying of any student based on the protected characteristics specified above or filing a complaint thereof.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School role at Orange is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At Orange, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At Orange, the Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - El Modena High School at Orange is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Manager II - Athletics (0992)
Job.JobDescription:
The Manager II - Athletics role at San Francisco Unified S.D. emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Manager II - Athletics coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At San Francisco Unified S.D., the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Manager II - Athletics reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent San Francisco Unified S.D. at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Manager II - Athletics may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Manager II - Athletics monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Manager II - Athletics must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at San Francisco Unified S.D..
Job.CompanyDescription: San Francisco Unified S.D. coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: EXL Soccer Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The EXL Soccer Coach at Mike Tsuboi is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the EXL Soccer Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Mike Tsuboi, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The EXL Soccer Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The EXL Soccer Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the EXL Soccer Coach at Mike Tsuboi allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary This position will oversee and coach the dance team(s). This person will be responsible for the audition process including but not limited to checking and assessing student eligibility, skill level, and appropriate permissions. During the year, the coach will: - Choreograph and manage the routines and trainings - Work with the facilities manager & Administration to schedule practices and performances - Work with Administration to coordinate travel and fundraising for competitions and costumes He/She needs to be someone who can communicate effectively with students, parents, and staff. Needs to know the school's discipline policies and maintain positive learning environment for students. Two years of competition dance experience preferred.

Job.JobTitle: Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School position at Rebecca Gutierrez is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At Rebecca Gutierrez, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Intramural Girls Basketball Coach @ Huntington Middle School role at Rebecca Gutierrez is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Athletic Coach Eligibility Pool - Villa Park High School
Job.JobDescription:
About the Employer The Orange Unified School District serves approximately 24,000 students in grades kindergarten through 12th and encompasses all or part of the cities of Anaheim, Garden Grove, Orange, Santa Ana and Villa Park. In 1953, the citizens of the area voted to form a "unified" school district, combining the original five elementary districts with the high school district into one unified district, now known as the Orange Unified School District. OUSD has a long history of excellence that continues to grow and be enriched by the accomplishments of its students, teachers, staff and community. -VISION - Our Commitment = Inspiring our learners of today to be purposeful leaders of tomorrow. -MISSION - Our Intention = In partnership with our community, we will provide a safe, equitable, and innovative culture of learning for each scholar to have a competitive EDGE as a leader. -CORE VALUES - Our Foundation = Integrity, Equity, Respect, and Excellence.
OUSD prohibits discrimination, intimidation, harassment, sexual harassment, or bullying based on a person's actual or perceived race, color, ancestry, national origin, ethnic group identification, age, religion, marital or parental status, physical or mental disability, sex, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity, gender expression, genetic information, or association with a person or a group with one or more of these actual or perceived characteristics - or any other basis protected by federal, state, or local law - in its educational programs, activities, or employment practices and provides equal access to the Boy Scouts of America and other designated youth groups.
The following have been designated to handle questions and complaints of alleged discrimination and are located at 1401 N. Job.JobTitle: Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School (2025-26)
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School role at John Hildebrand is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At John Hildebrand, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At John Hildebrand, the Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the Coach - Head Frosh Baseball @ West Park High School at John Hildebrand is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School role at Marysville Joint Unified Sch. Dist. emphasizes collaboration, consistency, and long‑term program development. This position is ideal for a coach who enjoys working as part of a broader athletic staff and who values building connections across grade levels and teams. The goal is to help create a smooth pathway for student‑athletes as they progress, while maintaining a recognizable identity and standard of excellence for the program.
In practical terms, the Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School coordinates closely with the athletic director and fellow coaches to align terminology, teaching priorities, and expectations. This might involve participating in coaching meetings, sharing practice plans, and adapting approaches so that athletes experience similar structures and messages at each level. At Marysville Joint Unified Sch. Dist., the program is strongest when coaches communicate and support one another.
Day‑to‑day responsibilities include designing practices that teach core skills, reinforcing team concepts, and preparing athletes for competition. The coach works to balance repetition with variety, ensuring that key fundamentals are constantly reinforced while athletes also experience new challenges. The Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School reviews performance with the team, helping athletes learn how to analyze both successes and mistakes in a constructive way.
The role extends into community and family engagement. Coaches represent Marysville Joint Unified Sch. Dist. at games, parent meetings, and potential youth outreach events. The Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School may help host clinics or camps, encourage younger students to try the sport, and provide information about expectations to families who are new to the program. A welcoming, organized presence can greatly influence how the program is perceived.
Athlete support is ongoing. The Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School monitors team morale, assists students in managing the demands of school and sport, and reinforces the importance of rest, nutrition, and healthy habits. The coach keeps the focus on sustainable growth rather than shortcuts, emphasizing that consistent effort over time leads to meaningful improvement.
Administrative tasks such as roster management, schedule communication, and equipment oversight are also part of the position. The Coach - Head Varsity Football - Marysville High School must handle these responsibilities reliably, as they are essential to maintaining a well‑run program. Coaches who enjoy seeing the big picture, who are willing to share ideas, and who care about the experience of every athlete will thrive in this role at Marysville Joint Unified Sch. Dist..

Job.JobTitle: Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) Pool
Job.JobDescription:
Description
Under the general supervision of the Division Dean of Humanities, Social Science, Education, Kinesiology and Athletics, the Adjunct Associate Professor of Coaching (Cheer Team) teaches organized classes primarily in the Coaching discipline; the primary responsibility is to teach up to 10 units (part-time) in the assigned discipline.
Responsibilities and Duties
Duties and responsibilities may include, but not limited to the following:
Instruct courses in Coaching in accordance with credit course outlines approved by the Board of Trustees. Maintain expertise in current teaching methods, discipline knowledge, and discipline specific technologies. Assist students in achieving stated course objectives. Evaluate the progress of each student and notify students in need of counseling services and/or tutorial assistance. Track student learning outcomes and maintain records of student learning outcomes. Participate in the departmental process of curriculum review, modification, and the assessment of student learning outcomes in order to make the program successful. Support the Division Dean in cooperating with campus and community groups to promote programs, courses, and information relevant to the needs of the students and various programs. Coordinate with other faculty in the selection of textbooks, audiovisual and other instructional materials. Complete various reporting procedures as required for student evaluation, course reporting and budget development. Assist the Division Dean in the preparation of required reports by providing requested information. Attend various departmental, divisional and campus-wide activities and events as required. Plan and complete approved professional development flex activities each semester. Perform other necessary duties as assigned by the Division Dean and as outlined in Board Policy.
MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS
Any bachelor’s degree and two years of professional experience, directly related to the faculty member’s teaching assignment; OR Any associate degree and six years of professional experience, directly related to the faculty member’s teaching assignment. A sensitivity to and understanding of the diverse academic, socioeconomic, cultural, disability, and ethnic backgrounds of community college students.
DESIRABLE QUALIFICATIONS
Previous coaching experience, preferably at the college level. Demonstrated ability to recruit student athletes. Demonstrated experience and ability to teach a variety of coaching related courses. Knowledge of California Community College Athletic Association (CCCAA) rules and regulations. Demonstrated ability to work effectively with students, faculty, and staff from diverse backgrounds.
Supplemental Information
NOTES: If you do not meet the minimum qualifications exactly as stated above, you must request an equivalency review and submit conclusive supporting documents at the time of application. Equivalency is defined as possessing the general education breadth and the major course work of the degree listed above, plus the experience defined above. If you need to request an equivalency review, please upload the equivalency form in the attachment section of the application.

Job.JobTitle: Boones Creek Softball Coach
Job.JobDescription:
The Boones Creek Softball Coach at Boones Creek Elementary School is a comprehensive coaching assignment where teaching, organization, and care for students come together in a single role. The coach is expected to be prepared, professional, and consistent, creating a framework in which athletes understand what is expected of them and feel supported in meeting those expectations. The program thrives when the coach brings a balanced focus on performance, safety, and personal development.
During practices, the Boones Creek Softball Coach manages time efficiently, moving athletes through warm‑ups, skill stations, team concepts, and competitive play. The coach provides instruction and feedback that is specific and actionable, helping athletes understand not just what to do, but why it matters. Attention is given to fundamentals, conditioning appropriate to the sport and season, and mental preparation for competition.
The position carries a strong responsibility for modeling behavior. At Boones Creek Elementary School, coaches are role models whether they are on the sideline, traveling with the team, or speaking with families. The Boones Creek Softball Coach demonstrates composure, fairness, and respect, even in emotionally charged situations. Athletes observe and imitate these behaviors, so the coach’s example has a direct impact on team culture.
The role also involves building strong connections with the broader school community. The coach collaborates with staff members, responds to communication from parents and guardians, and participates in department or school events as appropriate. Being visible and approachable helps families feel confident that their children are in a safe, supportive program.
Safety and compliance requirements form an important foundation. The Boones Creek Softball Coach follows all district and league regulations, maintains necessary certifications, and ensures that facilities and equipment are used appropriately. Emergency procedures are understood and practiced so that the team is prepared if an unexpected situation occurs.
This position is well suited to coaches who are detail‑oriented, who enjoy planning and facilitating engaging practices, and who care about the long‑term lessons students take away from their time in athletics. Serving as the Boones Creek Softball Coach at Boones Creek Elementary School allows a coach to influence not only competitive outcomes, but also the habits and character of the next generation.

Job.JobTitle: Ridgeview Baseball Head Coach
Job.JobDescription: Position Type: Athletics/Coaching/Coach (DBHS, FB, SS, RV, GES, or BCE) Date Posted: 6/20/2025 Location: Ridgeview Elementary School Role: Middle School Head Coach Education/Experiences: Not less than a high school education or general equivalency diploma; At least one (1) year of experience is preferred, but not required, so that with appropriate training, service may be provided in the specific role for which employed; and Meets necessary health and physical qualifications. Summary: Manage and supervise athletic activities, contests, and practice sessions to promote individual growth in athletic skills, teamwork, and good sportsmanship. Essential Duties/Responsibilities: Holds tryouts for team prospects and encourages students to participate. Assesses skills and determines team members and assigns team positions. Develops a regular practice schedule and organizes practice time to provide both individual and team development. Coaches and instructs players, individually and in groups, regarding the rules, regulations, equipment, and techniques of the sport. Monitors the academic performance of team members to ensure that eligibility requirements are maintained. Models sportsmanship-like behavior and reflects appropriate conduct towards players, school community, officials, and spectators regarding policies, procedures, performances, and problems. Communicates with the Principal and Athletic Director regarding policies, procedures, performances, and problems. Maintains eligibility forms, emergency data cards, physicals, equipment/uniform inventory, and other related records. Physical Demands: This job requires lifting of objects that exceed 50 lbs., or the average weight of a child, if assigned to elementary grades, with frequent lifting and/or carrying of objects weighing up to 25 lbs or more. Other physical demands that may be required are as follows: Pushing and/or pulling Climbing Stooping, kneeling and/or crawling Reaching Talking Hearing Seeing Vocational Preparation: The required vocational preparation may come from any of the following: Vocational education Apprentice training On-the-job training Essential experience in other jobs Temperament (Personal Traits): Adaptability to performing a variety of duties, often changing from one task to another of a different nature without loss of efficiency or composure. Adaptability to making generalizations, evaluations, or decisions based on sensory or judgmental criteria. Adaptability to dealing with students. Adaptability to making generalizations, evaluations, or decisions based on sensory or judgmental criteria. Capacity And Ability Requirements: Specific capacities and abilities may be required of an individual in order to learn or perform adequately a task or job duty. Intelligence: The ability to understand instructions and underlying principles. Ability to reason and make judgments. Verbal: Ability to understand meanings of words and ideas associated with them. Manual Dexterity: Ability to move the hands easily and skillfully. Form Perception: To make visual comparisons and discriminations and see slight differences in shapes and shadings of figures. Color Discrimination: Ability to perceive or recognize similarities or differences in colors or shades or other values of the same color. Work Conditions: Normal working environment. General Requirements: The above statements are intended to describe the general nature and level of work being performed by people assigned to this position. They are not intended to be a complete list of responsibilities, duties and skills required of personnel so assigned.
Job.Experience: At least one (1) year of experience is preferred

Job.JobTitle: Coach - Girls Volleyball
Job.JobDescription:
The Coach - Girls Volleyball at Lone Peak High School is a comprehensive coaching role that combines instruction, mentorship, and program management. This long‑form description reflects the multifaceted nature of school coaching, where the coach is both a technical expert and a caring adult presence in the lives of student‑athletes. The position is ideal for someone who values structure, communication, and collaboration while maintaining a clear focus on student development.
Day to day, the Coach - Girls Volleyball plans and leads practices that prioritize safety, learning, and steady improvement. A typical session might include dynamic warm‑ups, small‑group drills, competitive games, and review conversations that help athletes understand why they are working on certain skills. The coach explains expectations clearly, uses age‑appropriate language, and adapts instruction so that athletes at different experience levels can participate and progress.
Another key element of the job is fostering positive habits. Coaches at Lone Peak High School reinforce punctuality, preparedness, and respectful communication. The Coach - Girls Volleyball expects athletes to bring the proper equipment, to listen when others are speaking, and to take responsibility for their effort and behavior. When mistakes occur, the coach responds with guidance and accountability rather than embarrassment, reinforcing that learning is an ongoing process.
The role also emphasizes alignment with the school’s mission. Athletics is treated as part of the educational program, not as a separate or higher priority. That means the Coach - Girls Volleyball supports academic expectations, respects teachers’ roles, and encourages athletes to manage their time effectively. By checking in on grades and reinforcing eligibility requirements, the coach helps students see the connection between their everyday decisions and their opportunities to compete.
Operationally, the position involves logistics such as coordinating with transportation, ensuring facilities are left in good condition, communicating schedules, and maintaining equipment inventories. The coach understands district policies, league rules, and safety procedures, and follows them consistently. Maintaining required certifications and participating in professional development keeps the coach informed about best practices in training and athlete welfare.
In addition, the Coach - Girls Volleyball may contribute to long‑term program building through youth clinics, off‑season activities, and collaboration with other levels of the program. By investing in relationships with families and younger athletes, the coach helps sustain interest and continuity in the sport at Lone Peak High School. Candidates who enjoy balancing big‑picture planning with day‑to‑day teaching will find this position engaging and fulfilling.

Job.JobTitle: Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend
Job.JobDescription:
The Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend position at Skyline High provides an opportunity to guide student‑athletes through an experience that combines challenge, support, and growth. This role is intended for coaches who see beyond wins and losses and who value the lasting impact that a positive athletic program can have on young people. Through careful planning, consistent expectations, and ongoing communication, the coach helps create a framework where athletes can thrive.
From an instructional perspective, the Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend prepares practices that sequence learning effectively. Early sessions may focus heavily on fundamentals and basic systems, while later practices refine execution and introduce more advanced concepts. The coach uses demonstrations, targeted drills, and guided scrimmages to help athletes apply what they learn. Regular assessment allows the coach to adjust plans based on the team’s progress.
The position also requires deliberate attention to team culture. At Skyline High, the Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend works to ensure that the environment is welcoming, fair, and focused on collective responsibility. The coach sets expectations around effort, communication, and respect, and follows through when those expectations are not met. Celebrating positive examples and giving athletes leadership opportunities strengthens the sense of ownership within the group.
Support for the broader student experience is built into the job. Coaches stay informed about academic calendars, test periods, and other school events so that practices and competitions are scheduled thoughtfully whenever possible. The Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend encourages athletes to communicate about conflicts in advance and to take initiative in managing their commitments. When students feel supported in both academics and athletics, they are more likely to remain engaged and successful.
Administrative responsibilities include coordination with the athletic department, assisting with transportation, submitting required paperwork, and maintaining accurate rosters. The coach must be attentive to detail and willing to complete these tasks reliably, as they directly affect the experience of athletes and families.
At its core, the Soccer, Head Coach - Girls - with Stipend at Skyline High is a chance to teach, to mentor, and to build something that extends beyond a single season. Candidates who are motivated by the opportunity to help students grow through sport will find this position especially meaningful.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Swim Coach - Alta High
Job.JobDescription:
Job Summary
Alta High School is seeking an enthusiastic and dedicated Assistant Swim Coach to support our swim program. The ideal candidate will work closely with the Head Coach to develop athletes' skills, foster team spirit, and promote both competitive success and personal growth in student-athletes.
Responsibilities
Assist in planning and conducting daily swim practices, dryland workouts, and conditioning sessions. Provide individual feedback to swimmers on stroke technique, starts, turns, and race strategies. Help organize meet lineups, attend meets, and support athletes during competition. Promote good sportsmanship, teamwork, and academic responsibility. Assist with team communication, record-keeping, and other administrative tasks as needed. Ensure the safety and well-being of all athletes during practices and competitions. Collaborate with the Head Coach and other coaching staff to create a positive and inclusive team environment. Support the Head Coach in managing team equipment and facilities. Stay current with coaching techniques, rules, and best practices in swimming.
Qualifications
Previous coaching or competitive swimming experience preferred. Knowledge of swimming techniques, training methods, and competition rules. Strong communication, organizational, and interpersonal skills. Ability to work effectively with high school students, parents, and school staff. First Aid and CPR certification preferred (or willingness to obtain). Must pass a background check and meet all district and state requirements for coaching positions.

Job.JobTitle: COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW
Job.JobDescription:
The COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW position at SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the COACH, BOYS LACROSSE - SKY VIEW role at SKY VIEW HIGH SCHOOL is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach Boys Soccer
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Coach Boys Soccer at Grantsville High School is designed for a coach who believes that athletics is a powerful tool for teaching life skills. This role centers on developing student‑athletes as people first and competitors second, helping them learn responsibility, perseverance, and teamwork in a structured and supportive environment. The program places a strong emphasis on clear communication, mutual respect, and long‑term development rather than short‑term results alone.
On a daily basis, the Assistant Coach Boys Soccer is responsible for planning and delivering practices that are active, safe, and inclusive. Training sessions should include a balance of fundamentals, decision‑making drills, and live or game‑like situations so that athletes are constantly learning. The coach provides direct instruction, demonstrates proper technique, and offers individualized feedback to help each athlete progress from their current skill level.
In addition to technical coaching, this position carries significant mentoring responsibilities. At Grantsville High School, coaches are expected to build positive relationships with student‑athletes and to support them through the challenges of school, competition, and adolescence. That means listening carefully, encouraging good choices, and reinforcing expectations related to attendance, academic effort, and personal conduct. The Assistant Coach Boys Soccer helps create a team environment where athletes feel valued and where they understand that their actions affect the group.
The role also includes collaboration with the broader athletic department. The Assistant Coach Boys Soccer works with the athletic director and other coaches to coordinate facility use, align program philosophies, and support multi‑sport participation when possible. Sharing information, attending department meetings, and contributing to school‑wide initiatives all help ensure that the program at Grantsville High School operates smoothly and consistently from season to season.
Game‑day responsibilities include preparing athletes physically and mentally, organizing lineups, communicating adjustments, and modeling composure in competitive situations. The coach is expected to represent Grantsville High School with professionalism toward officials, opponents, and fans. After competitions, the Assistant Coach Boys Soccer reviews performance with the team, highlighting effort, improvement, and areas for growth.
Health and safety are a constant priority. The coach follows district and state guidelines for equipment use, conditioning progressions, and emergency response. Maintaining appropriate certifications and staying current with best practices helps ensure that every training and competition environment is as safe as possible for all participants. Candidates who care deeply about student development, enjoy teaching the details of the sport, and are committed to a positive, educational approach to athletics will be strong fits for the Assistant Coach Boys Soccer role at Grantsville High School.
