The Assistant Coach - Softball - Parowan High School also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the Assistant Coach - Softball - Parowan High School role at Parowan High School is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.
Job.CompanyDescription: Iron County School Dist coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554]
Job.JobDescription:
The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554] at Ben Lomond High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554] is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At Ben Lomond High School, the Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554] helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554] may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents Ben Lomond High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Assistant Boys Soccer Coach [ESP3554] follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
Job.CompanyDescription: Ogden City School Dist coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity)
Job.JobDescription:
The 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity) role at York High School is focused on building a competitive, well‑organized program that still prioritizes the overall well‑being of student‑athletes. This position blends strategy, culture‑building, and teaching, providing the coach with an opportunity to influence the direction of the program for years to come. The successful candidate will bring a clear vision for how to teach the sport, how to manage a team, and how to represent the school in a positive and professional manner.
From a competitive standpoint, the 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity) is responsible for developing seasonal plans that align practice content, conditioning work, and game preparation. This includes designing practice segments that progress from individual fundamentals to full‑team tactical execution. The coach should be comfortable breaking down film, identifying areas for improvement, and communicating game plans in a way that athletes can understand and apply under pressure.
Equally important is the culture created by the coach. At York High School, teams are expected to demonstrate sportsmanship, respect, and unity. The 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity) sets standards for effort in practice, behavior in the classroom, and conduct in the community. That might involve establishing team guidelines, leading discussions about values, and recognizing athletes who demonstrate leadership or growth in those areas. The goal is to build a program where success is measured not just by wins and losses but by the quality of the experience for everyone involved.
This position also involves close coordination with the academic side of the school. The coach monitors eligibility, encourages students to keep up with assignments, and celebrates academic milestones. Communicating with teachers and counselors when necessary helps support student‑athletes as whole people, not just as performers in one activity. At York High School, the 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity) is viewed as part of the educational team.
Program administration tasks include managing equipment and uniforms, tracking inventory, assisting with scheduling, and following all district and league regulations. The coach should be organized, punctual, and attentive to details such as transportation arrangements and roster paperwork. Safety protocols, including emergency action planning and injury‑reporting procedures, must be consistently followed.
Overall, the 2025-2026 Head Soccer Coach (Girls Varsity) at York High School is best suited for a coach who is excited about teaching, willing to collaborate with colleagues, and prepared to invest in the growth of student‑athletes over multiple seasons. It is an opportunity to provide structure, challenge, and support while representing the school with pride in the larger athletic community.
Job.CompanyDescription: York County coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Head Mens Soccer Coach at Juanita High School
Job.JobDescription:
Juanita High School (part of the Juanita Learning Community) is seeking qualified candidates for a position as Head Men's Soccer Coach for the 2025-2026 school year. This is a head coach level position.
Season: 3/2/2026 - 5/9/2026 Certificated Stipend: $6,150 per the season Classified hourly rate: $25.63 per hour (240 hour calendar) There are no benefits assigned to this position.
LICENSE REQUIREMENTS: Proof of valid First Aid, AED and CPR Adult & Child certification is required upon hire. ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS: High School diploma or equivalent required. Must be minimum of 21 years old for Head Coach position. QUALIFICATIONS: Must be able to motivate student athletics and maintain positive rapport with players and parents. Must be organized in management of equipment, statistics and written record. Communicate effectively both orally and in writing. Must meet and abide by LWSD policies and guidelines, (first aid, CPR, AED, HIV, HBV, fingerprinting, Expectations for Employee Conduct class, references, orientation, and eligibility work form). Must meet minimum age requirements per the Washington Interscholastic Activities Association (WIAA). Must meet WIAA experience level coach's standards and follow their rules and regulations. Prior successful high school coaching experience. Demonstrated cooperation with school administration in promoting the total athletic program. Must be able to organize, supervise, coordinate, and evaluate practice sessions and related activities. Demonstrated proper sportsmanship responsibilities as a good role model for parents, students and fans. Must be able to communicate and enforce training rules and athletic code. Must pass criminal background check.

Job.CompanyDescription: Kent coaching jobs

Job.JobTitle: Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School
Job.JobDescription:
The Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School at Evergreen Middle School is a high‑engagement coaching role that calls for energy, clear communication, and a steady presence for student‑athletes. This position is built for a coach who enjoys being actively involved in every aspect of the program, from leading warm‑ups and teaching tactics to meeting with families and coordinating logistics. The coach is expected to bring consistency and enthusiasm to each interaction with the team.
Practices led by the Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School are structured and purposeful. They begin with appropriate warm‑ups, transition into focused skill work, and conclude with competitive or situational activities that resemble live play. The coach introduces concepts in manageable steps and checks for understanding, encouraging athletes to ask questions and learn the reasoning behind drills and strategies. This approach helps athletes become smarter, more confident players.
Motivation is another key component of the job. Coaches at Evergreen Middle School use positive reinforcement, high yet realistic expectations, and clear feedback to help athletes push themselves. The Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School recognizes effort and improvement, not just outcomes, and supports athletes through setbacks. This creates an environment where students are willing to take risks and grow.
The role also includes a strong communication element. The coach keeps families informed about schedules, travel, and program expectations, and responds to questions in a respectful, timely manner. Within the school, the Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School collaborates with administrators and teachers to support students’ academic responsibilities, reinforcing that success in the classroom is essential.
Finally, the position requires adherence to safety and policy standards. The Basketball - Assistant Coach - Girls - Middle School maintains appropriate supervision ratios, follows guidelines on equipment use, and ensures that emergency procedures are understood and practiced. The coach models appropriate conduct toward officials and opponents, reinforcing that competing with integrity is a core expectation at Evergreen Middle School. This comprehensive role is well suited to coaches who are organized, student‑focused, and eager to contribute to a strong athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach- Boys Soccer
Job.JobDescription:
The Head Coach- Boys Soccer role at Mountainview is focused on helping student‑athletes unlock their potential through intentional coaching, structured practice environments, and a strong emphasis on character. This description outlines a position in which the coach is expected to be a planner, a teacher, a mentor, and a positive representative of the school community. Successful candidates bring energy to practices, patience to instruction, and clarity to expectations.
Practices form the backbone of the program, and the Head Coach- Boys Soccer is responsible for designing sessions that are purposeful and efficient. Each practice should have defined goals, from teaching new concepts to reinforcing previously learned skills or preparing for upcoming competition. The coach uses a variety of drills and teaching methods to keep athletes engaged, and regularly evaluates whether the team is progressing in the desired areas.
Coaches at Mountainview are also trusted to guide student‑athletes through challenges. That can include addressing frustrations after a tough loss, helping a student handle the pressure of increased responsibility, or supporting someone who is balancing school, family, and activities. The Head Coach- Boys Soccer listens, provides perspective, and reinforces the idea that effort, attitude, and resilience are as important as any statistical outcome.
Communication is a key strength of this position. The coach shares information about schedules, team policies, and expectations with families and staff in a timely and professional way. Within the team, the Head Coach- Boys Soccer encourages athletes to ask questions, give feedback, and support one another. This open communication helps prevent misunderstandings and builds trust.
Safety and compliance cannot be overlooked. The Head Coach- Boys Soccer follows all relevant policies regarding equipment, supervision, travel, and emergency procedures. The coach maintains current certifications as required and keeps up with best practices around conditioning, concussion awareness, and hydration. At Mountainview, the well‑being of student‑athletes is non‑negotiable.
This role is a good match for coaches who appreciate structure, care deeply about students, and are committed to building a consistent, values‑driven program. By serving as the Head Coach- Boys Soccer at Mountainview, a coach has the opportunity to make a lasting impact on young people while contributing to a respected and sustainable athletic tradition.

Job.JobTitle: Head Dance Coach
Job.JobDescription:
Position Type: Athletics/Coach Date Posted: 5/30/2025 Location: Canyon Ridge Middle School Closing Date: until filled Assignment Type Seasonal Season Stipend Min: $4,526 Max: $5,580 Stipend Schedule Middle School Coaches Salary Schedule Placement based on years of coaching experience. Benefits Employee Benefits | Kent School District
All coaching positions are posted as open until filled. Any applicants that apply within 5 days of initial posting are guaranteed consideration per the Coaches collective bargaining agreement.
Persons applying for paid coaching positions must meet district and WIAA requirements including a valid background check. Applicants for head coaching positions must be at least 21 years of age. Applicants for assistant coaching positions must be at least 19 years of age. They must also have a valid first aid and CPR card. The following procedures must be followed to apply for paid coaching positions:
1. Complete the KSD online application process including professional reference forms. 2. Annually complete the WIAA general rules clinic, the WIAA-approved rule clinic for the sport being coached, and the KSD Vector Training requirements prior to the beginning of the sports season. 3. Have successfully completed Concussion recognition and management with Return to Play Protocols training as required by Washington State Law that must be renewed every three (3) years. 4. Have successfully completed Sudden Cardiac Arrest Awareness and Training as required by Washington State Law that must be renewed every three (3) years. 5. Before the beginning of the third year of coaching, a member school coach (paid or volunteer) must complete a school district-approved Coaching Principles training, or complete the NFHS Coaches Fundamentals Course, or attend all sessions of the WIAA Coaches School, or other Coaches School as approved by the WIAA or the local school district. After initial completion, coaches will be required to repeat this training every three (3) years 6. Building athletic directors will monitor the applicant pool for their open positions and contact applicants as necessary. 7. If hired, the paid coach must read and sign the KSD Coaches Manual.
About Kent School District...

Job.JobTitle: Head Coach- Girls Water Polo
Job.JobDescription: Please see attached Job Description for additional information. Auburn School District Human Resources prioritizes equity as a fundamental principle, emphasizing the removal of barriers and the promotion of inclusive practices to ensure all staff and students can thrive. This principle guides our practices, operations, and resource allocations. We actively recruit and hire individuals who are passionately dedicated to fostering an equitable environment for all. We welcome and are actively seeking applications from those committed to working in partnership with us to support this vision who share our values and are eager to contribute to creating a welcoming, inclusive atmosphere where everyone feels valued, respected, and a true sense of belonging. Auburn School District's Non-Discrimination Statement Auburn School District complies with all federal rules and regulations and does not illegally discriminate on the basis of age; gender; race; color; creed; religion; national origin (including language); sex; sexual orientation including gender expression or identity; honorably discharged veteran or military status; the presence of any sensory, mental or physical disability; the use of a trained dog guide or service animal; and provides equal access to the Boy Scouts and other designated youth. Inquiries regarding compliance procedures may be directed to: Civil Rights Compliance Coordinator and Title IX for Staff Jon Young, jyoung@auburn.wednet.edu, (253) 931-4932; Title IX Coordinator Students: Rhonda Larson, rlarson@auburn.wednet.edu, (253) 931-4900; 504 Coordinator, Alexander Siwiec, asiwiec@auburn.wednet.edu, (253) 931-4927, Auburn School District 915 4th St NE, Auburn, WA, 98002.

Job.JobTitle: Assistant Coach General Posting 2025 - 2026 School Year
Job.JobDescription: This posting will be used to generate a 2025-2026 applicant pool for Assistant Coach positions at both middle and high school levels. If you are interested in being considered for an Assistant Coach position and there is no school specific posting currently open for that sport, please apply to this posting. Please be sure to complete the entire application and include a resume on the Supplemental Materials page of application. Do include your current day job as well as most recent coaching experience position at a minimum on the Experience page of the application. Pay rate and season calendar vary with sport and grade level. See the Non-Represented Stipend Schedule 2025 - 2026 here. There are no benefits assigned to this position. LICENSE REQUIREMENTS: Proof of valid First Aid, AED and CPR Adult and Child certification is required upon hire. ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS: High School diploma or equivalent required. Must be minimum of 19 years old for Assistant Coach position. APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS: Internal and External Applicants: Complete an online application https://www.applitrack.com/lakewashington/onlineapp/default.aspx Please review LWSD Human Resources Employment Policies, which includes our non-discrimination policy. We are not able to sponsor employment at this time. Lake Washington School District is committed to building an inclusive, equitable, and welcoming environment for all students and staff. We welcome candidates from all backgrounds and life experiences who share our commitment to educational excellence and equity. We especially encourage applications from individuals who have been historically underrepresented in education. LAKE WASHINGTON SCHOOL DISTRICT IS A SMOKE-FREE WORKPLACE.
Job.Benefits: There are no benefits assigned to this position.

Job.JobTitle: 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys)
Job.JobDescription:
The 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys) position at East High is an opportunity to shape a positive, inclusive, and hardworking team environment where students learn to love their sport and take pride in representing their school. This role emphasizes relationship‑building, clear expectations, and steady improvement over the course of a season and across multiple years of participation. The coach serves as a daily presence in the lives of student‑athletes, modeling the type of attitude and work ethic that leads to both athletic and personal growth.
At the core of the job is teaching. The 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys) is responsible for breaking down complex skills into manageable steps, offering demonstrations, and creating drills that allow athletes to practice safely and effectively. Practices should be organized around clear objectives, with time built in for warm‑up, instruction, repetition, and review. The coach gives frequent feedback, adjusts activities based on what athletes need, and encourages questions so that students remain engaged in their learning.
The role also involves nurturing team chemistry and a sense of belonging. At East High, coaches work to make sure every athlete feels included and respected. That means setting guidelines that prevent negative behavior, addressing conflicts quickly and fairly, and celebrating contributions from both starters and role players. The 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys) encourages athletes to support one another, communicate openly, and take pride in representing their school with class.
Beyond the field, court, track, or pool, the coach collaborates with school staff to support student‑athletes as whole people. That includes reinforcing academic expectations, respecting school policies, and helping students manage the demands of both athletics and coursework. Regular contact with families keeps everyone informed about schedules, expectations, and program goals, and offers a consistent channel for questions or concerns.
The 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys) also participates in broader program responsibilities such as attending department meetings, assisting with youth outreach or clinics, and contributing to long‑term planning. The coach is expected to stay current with best practices in training, injury prevention, and sport‑specific strategy, and to maintain any certifications required by the district or state association.
For individuals who enjoy working with young people, who believe in the value of school‑based athletics, and who are prepared to invest time in building a healthy team culture, the 25-26 - East - Track and Field Associate Head Coach (Boys) role at East High is a meaningful and impactful opportunity.

Job.JobTitle: Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year
Job.JobDescription:
The Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year at West High School is an integral member of the school's educational team, using athletics as a platform for teaching discipline, teamwork, and perseverance. This position calls for a coach who is organized, reflective, and committed to continuous improvement, both for themselves and for their athletes. The role blends hands‑on coaching with program administration and relationship‑building.
From a coaching standpoint, the Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year is responsible for teaching the rules, techniques, and strategies of the sport in a way that is accessible to student‑athletes. Practices are planned to include progressive skill work, position‑specific instruction, and opportunities for athletes to apply learning in controlled scrimmage situations. The coach pays attention to pacing and variety so that sessions remain engaging while still challenging students to stretch their comfort zones.
Culture is a central focus of this job. At West High School, the Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year helps create a team environment where respect, honesty, and effort are expected. The coach sets clear standards regarding communication, attendance, and sportsmanship, and works with athletes to understand why these standards matter. When expectations are not met, the coach responds fairly, explaining consequences and encouraging athletes to learn from mistakes.
The position also requires responsiveness to student needs. Coaches remain aware of the emotional and academic pressures students face and adjust support accordingly. Checking in with athletes, acknowledging their efforts, and partnering with school staff all contribute to a positive experience. The Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year may assist in connecting students with resources when additional support is needed.
Outside of direct coaching, the role involves tasks such as coordinating with officials and opponents, assisting with scheduling, and managing team communication channels. The coach must be punctual, prepared, and detail‑oriented, ensuring that events run smoothly and that the team represents West High School well at home and away.
Safety remains an ongoing responsibility. The Cheer - Assistant Coach - West High School 25/26 School Year follows district guidelines, maintains necessary certifications, and emphasizes proper warm‑up routines and technique to minimize risk of injury. This comprehensive approach to coaching allows student‑athletes to pursue their goals in a structured environment that prioritizes learning, well‑being, and long‑term success.
